summary.seg: This is a composite manuscript, comprised of two Parts. The first Part was probably made in England in the second half of the 15th century and is a copy of the 'short' version of William Lyndwood's Constitutiones, i.e. without an accompanying commentary. The second Part was perhaps made in France in the second half of the 13th century or the early 14th century and contains a copy of one of the recensions of the Dominican Raymund of Peñafort's Summa de casibus poenitentiae, a guide for confessors on hearing confession and considering an appropriate penance.

The manuscript was donated to Emmanuel College by Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) Leigh, Thomas (d. 1686) , fellow of Emmanuel c. 1657-1665, who inscribed his name in the upper margin of f. 1:1r. Although the date of Leigh's donation of this manuscript is not known, Leigh donated other manuscripts to Emmanuel in 1667 and it is presumed that MS 66 joined the Emmanuel library collection at the same time. The manuscript was probably composite by 1667, and was certainly composite by 1697 when it was described in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697) as 'Provinciales Conftituiones Angliae cum Tabula, Chartaceus liber ; cui tamen alia quaedam adduntur in membranis optime descripta'; Part 1 of the manuscript is written on paper, and Part 2 on well-made parchment, i.e., the 'membranis optime descripta' in Bernard's description.

The closing flyleaves ff. [v] verso-[vi] recto in the volume have been used for notes and annotations, in this case to record medical recipes mostly in Latin, and one in Middle English, written by several 15th-century hands.

References:
Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697)

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: Parchment endleaves, paper leaves in Part 1, parchment leaves in Part 2.

foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of the first recto of each quire beginning at Quire 2 (f. 1:13). The unfoliated endleaves were assigned the designations ff. [i] - [iii] and [iv] - [vi] in order to prepare a TEI-XML catalogue record for this item during the Curious Cures project, these designations are enclosed in [square brackets] throughout the record. As the foliation sequence restarts at the beginning of Part 2, folio references to Part 1 are given in the form 1:1r etc., and folio references to Part 2 are given in the form 2:1r etc.

supportDesc.collation:
A composite volume in two Parts, the quires arranged as follows:
Quire 112 (ff. 1:1-1:12)
Quire 212-1 (1st leaf missing; ff. 1:13-1:23)
Quires 3-512 (ff. 1:24-1:59) |
Quire 612-1 (1st leaf excised; ff. 2:1-11)
Quires 7-1312 (ff. 2:12-2:95)
112 212-1 (1st leaf missing) 3-512 | 612-1 (1st leaf excised) 7-1312
No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
No quire signatures common to the entire volume. No catchwords common to the entire volume.

note.p: Medical recipes in ink in Latin and Middle English in at least two 15th-century hands on ff. [v] verso - [vi] recto. The Middle English recipe 'For the stone' is printed in IMEP 22, p. 13.
The name 'William James' in ink on f. [vi] recto by a 17th-century hand.

binding.p: Mid-17th century binding. Fully bound in leather over pulp-boards with matching decoration in blind to left and right covers. Covers are decorated with a triple-fillet frame with Oxford corners set at the perimeter of the boards. Head and tail bands visible, perhaps yarn over a cord core, but heavily stained with glue and red pigment. Four raised bands on spine, each with a single-fillet through their centre across the width of the spine. Spine compartments are decorated with a double fillet at their upper and lower perimeters and at the upper and lower openings of the spine. Four printed paper labels fixed to the spine with an adhesive, 'MSS.', '1', '3', '14', for a former shelfmark.
Head, fore, and tail edges of the bookblock sprinkled with red.

Pastedowns have been lifted and the inner faces of the boards are exposed. The inside of the right cover is blank. The inside of the left cover contains the following items:
The number '70' in pencil set in a lozenge frame for the M. R. James Catalogue number of the volume
The former shelfmark 'MSS 1. 3. 14' in ink and pencil
An Emmanuel College armorial bookplate by Metcalfe of Cambridge: a lion rampant in the right paw a laurel wreath with the motto "ΕΜΜΑΝΟΥΗΛ" (the Greek form of 'Emmanuel') on the escutcheon and the words 'Collegii Emmanuelis Liber' below

The endleaves ff. [i] and [vi] are former pastedowns, and both bear traces of adhesive on their outermost faces. The endleaf f. [iii] verso contains the following items:
The number '54' in ink
A description of the contents of the volume in ink in a humanist hand 'Provinciale Guilielmi Lynwood'
Dimensions (L x W x D): 205 x 145 x 50 mm.
Housed in a dark blue box with a label 'MS 66' stamped in gold and bearing a label on the inside of the box 'This box was made using a generous donation from Mark Drinkwater 2014'.
Evidence of two metal clasps belonging to a former binding visible on f. [i] recto as small green metallic-oxide stains along the fore edge of the leaf.

provenance.p: Owned by Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) Leigh, Thomas (d. 1686) , fellow of Emmanuel c. 1657-1665. Leigh's name is present in the upper margin of f. 1:1r as 'Tho: Leigh.'

acquisition.p: Given to Emmanuel College probably in 1667 by Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) Leigh, Thomas (d. 1686) , fellow of Emmanuel c. 1657-1665.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M. R. James in The Western manuscripts in the library of Emmanuel College A descriptive catalogue (Cambridge, 1904), no. 66.

availability.p: Visitors to Emmanuel College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Emmanuel College: Special Collections.

custodialHist.custEvent: Number 29 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697)

monogr.title: Manuscripts in Christ's, Emmanuel, Jesus, Selwyn and Sidney Colleges, Trinity Hall, Cambridge

analytic.title: The First Readers of Lyndwood's Provinciale

msItem.title: Prouinciale
msItem.author: William Lyndwood
msItem.rubric: 1:1r De summa trinitate et fide catholica
msItem.incipit: 1:1r Ignorancia sacerdotum etcetera . Ne quis per ignoranciam se excuset
msItem.note: There are two main versions of this text: copies of the Constitutiones with additional commentary, and copies of the Constitutiones alone; this is the latter of the two main types. Titles to the individual Constitutiones are written in ink in the upper margin on most leaves, and most have been partially damaged by later trimming.
Index to the laws and where they were made on ff. 1:55v-1:59r. Folio 1:59v is blank.

listBibl.bibl: Edition (not based on this MS) Provinciale (seu Constitutiones Angliæ,) (Oxford, 1679)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in ink in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire, and on occasional non-end-of-quire versos throughout the Part, see e.g., f. 35v and f. 18v.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition although somewhat tightly bound; some text near the inner margins is difficult to read. Some marginal annotations damaged by or lost to trimming.

p.seg: Folios 1:1r-1:55r ruled in ink, frame only. Ruled in single-column format, typically 28 lines to the page and written below top line.
Folios 1:55v-1:59r ruled in ink, frame only. Ruled in triple-column format for an index, typically 28 lines to the page and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a cursiva libraria with many anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Plain initals in red or blue at the major and minor divisions of the text.

origin.origDate: Written in the 15th century, probably in the second half

note.p: Date and location of production assigned based on the palaeographical features of this Part.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 2 - Raymond of Peñafort, Summa de casibus poenitentiae

msItem.title: Summa de casibus poenitentiae
msItem.author: Raymund of Peñafort (b. ?1175, d. 1275)
msItem.incipit: 2:1r Distinguitur hoc opus in tres particulas
msItem.explicit: 2:95r et ineffabilem iocunditatis vocem illam . Venite benedicte patres mei percipite regnum etc
msItem.finalRubric: 2:95r Finito libro sit laus et gloria christo hic liber est scriptus qui scripsit sit benedictus
msItem.note: In three books. List of capitula to Book 1 on f. 2:1r, Book 2 begins on f. 2:24r with a list of capitula, and Book 3 begins on f. 2:42r with no list of capitula.

Not listed among the surviving copies of this text in L. Robles, 'Escritores dominicos de la Corona de Aragón (siglos XIII–XV)', in Repertorio de historia de las ciencias eclesiásticas en España (Salamanca, 1967-1979), pp. 14-31.

listBibl.bibl: Edition, not based on this MS in Universa bibliotheca iuris 1B, ed. by X. Ochoa and A. Diez (Rome, 1976)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In generally good condition, but too tightly bound and text adjacent to the inner margins is difficult to read. There is liquid damage to the lower half of the leaves in this Part, but legibility is not significantly impaired by the stain. Some leaves have a slightly irregular shape or size, typically because their lower margin has been trimmed carelessly, which has caused the loss of some text, see e.g., ff. 2:60r-2:63v.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and lines, line ruling very faint. Ruled in two-column format, typically 48 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a small and precise northern textualis libraria.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials in red and blue at the major and some minor divisions of the text, a particularly ornate initial on f. 2:1r.
Plain initials in red or blue at some minor divisions of the text.
Paraph marks in red or blue.

origin.origDate: Written in the 13th century, probably in the second half

note.p: Date and location of production suggested based on the palaeographical features of this Part.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer for Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
